utterances: (LAUGHTER)
Well, Carol, thanks very much for the call.
I appreciate it.
Thank you for taking my call.
Bye.
Patt Morrison, what happens to the flowers after the parade's over?
The floats go on display in a park in Pasadena.
So for a couple of days, people can go look at them.
And you can get as sense, when they're stationary, of the scale.
And as Carol was saying, people glue individual seeds, sunflower seeds, any vegetation is fair game for these floats.
All that has to be affixed to the float.
And one of the barns she talks about, one of the warehouses is down the street from KPCC.

So before the parade in the weeks before, you can see the floats doing little practice runs when they go up and down the street and to be able to say I'm sorry I'm late for work, I was blocked by a Rose Parade float.

Catherine(ph) emailed: The parade means being a child in 1950, climbing up the wooden ladder my father loaded into the car high enough to see above the heads of the crowd, snorting horses, high school bands, and I think Roy Rogers - all great excitement.

Only when I was 17 working as a temporary Christmas clerk at (unintelligible) along with one of the Rose Parade princess - Rose Parade princesses - did I realize how much artifice is required to hold up the community belief in pure fantasy.
(LAUGHTER)
Well put.
Patt Morrison, thanks very much for your time today.
Always a pleasure, Neal.
Happy New Year.
Happy New Year to you.
Patt Morrison, the columnist from Los Angeles Times and special correspondent for our member station in Pasadena, KPCC.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
Tomorrow, it's the Political Junkie.
Ken Rudin will be here.
I'm Neal Conan, NPR News in Washington.
No.
OK, so naming a VA clinic and, for example, repeal and replacing Obamacare would each be one point on the legislative scoreboard, but they're very different kinds of bills.
Very different.
And 2 of the 28 bills do actually name VA facilities.
But 13 of the measures are significant, and they're part of something called the Congressional Review Act.
That allows Congress to overturn rules created by federal agencies that haven't yet taken effect.
So President Trump and the Republican Congress came in, and they said, we want to overturn a bunch of these Obama-era rules.
And some of those are significant.
This included a stream protection rule.
Environmentalists, Democrats say that this is an important environmental protection.
Republicans and others say that it was hurting the coal industry.
So when you look at the legislative scorecard that the White House puts out now and compare it to the campaign promises that candidate Trump made, how do they compare?
They're kind of apples and oranges.
When candidate Trump in October put out his contract with the American voter, he said that he was going to introduce and push for the passage of 10 bills.
Of those 10 bills, only one has been introduced, and that is the measure to repeal and replace Obamacare.
As we know, that is...
That didn't pass.
It did not.
It didn't even get a vote.
Right.
It may get a vote at some point some time.
They don't want to put a timetable on it.
And then there's the tax reform measure that isn't a measure yet, that is broad principles that Scott talked about - not a bill yet.
But the Trump administration would argue this is not how a Republican president should be judged.
A Democratic president wants to create things, wants to make programs.
A Republican president wants to undo regulation.
They want government to do less.
They want it to be smaller.
Exactly.
And in that respect, the Trump administration says, look; we've done these 13 rule rollbacks.
And they say the biggest legislative accomplishment they point to is getting Neil Gorsuch confirmed to the Supreme Court.
When we're talking about legislation passed in the first 100 days, it's not only a referendum on the president.
This is also about Congress, right?
It absolutely is and how the president works with Congress.
And even if his party controls both Houses of Congress, things don't necessarily happen quickly or easily.
George W.
Bush's first tax cut, his No Child Left Behind law - those didn't happen in his first 100 days.
President Obama got the stimulus bill passed, but he didn't get Obamacare or Dodd-Frank done until much later.
So for President Trump, if at the end of this year he hasn't gotten a significant legislative accomplishment, he will not be judged kindly.
NPR's Tamara Keith, thanks for the explanation.
You're welcome.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
More than 800,000 people in the Southeast are still without power following Hurricane Katrina.
Entire towns along the Gulf Coast are little more than splinters.
Those who remain in New Orleans are under a mandatory evacuation order as officers continue to go house to house.
And even though the pumps are starting to do their work, much of the city's infrastructure will spend the next several weeks sitting in contaminated water.
On his first visit to the area, President Bush pledged to rebuild what the storm took away, but there are no easy answers for communities devastated by Katrina.
Along the Mississippi coast, residents wait for federal reconstruction money and for decisions about the return of the casino industry.
In New Orleans, the questions are even more fundamental.

What can be salvaged by the floodwater, how much can both the government and the private sector--how much will they rebuild, how can a city that is slowly sinking further below sea level protect itself from future disasters and they're asking about the size and the character of the new New Orleans?
This is not the first American city to have its future threatened by natural disaster.
San Francisco rebuilt after its earthquake; Chicago after its fire.
But Galveston never quite came back from its storm and there are still people living in tents in Florida trying to reconstruct what last year's hurricanes took away.
Today we look at what stories of other disaster-stricken communities can teach us about the future for Katrina's victims.
Later on in the program, Governor Schwarzenegger's dilemma; he's got a gay marriage bill on his desk, and trouble whether he signs it or not.
But first, rebuilding is the TALK OF THE NATION.
If you lost your home or your entire community to a natural disaster, flood, fire, hurricane earthquake--did you rebuild?
Why or why not?
And if you did rebuild, how did it change the character of your town?
Join the conversation.
Our number is (800) 989-8255.
That's (800) 989-TALK.
The e-mail address is totn@npr.org.
The slow, difficult work of rebuilding goes on long after the media has turned its eyes to other stories.
We first talked with Florida postman Chuck Cantasano last year when he was delivering the mail right after his town and his house were devastated by Hurricane Charley.
He joins us again today by cell phone.
He happens to be in Disney World today.
Charlie, thanks for taking the time out from vacation to talk with us.
It's a pleasure, Neal.
What kind of shape is your town--Punta Gorda, what kind of shape is it in today?
Little by little it's being rebuilt.
You have a lot of people have spent a lot of money and a lot of time.

What seems to be going in has been done in a much better and safer way and--but then, you know, you go down the block and you find vacant lots, still, homes that have been literally untouched from the day after the hurricane.
What's the hardest part of rebuilding?
Walter Peacock, you studied what happened after Hurricane Andrew.
Does--how does--demographics, how did that change after a storm?

Hi, Scott.

That's right.
Japan has been feeling the squeeze of the steel tariffs that the president imposed not long ago.
Those tariffs add 25 percent to the price of steel that is imported from Japan.
A lot of other big foreign steel suppliers, including Canada and South Korea, got a reprieve from those tariffs partly as a result of trade talks.
And Trump would like to press Japan into some kind of bilateral trade deal.
But so far, Tokyo has not been interested in that.

had a trade deficit with Japan of about $56 billion.
